newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks end higher on continued fervour.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks end higher on continued fervour.

text.p: Taiwan share prices finished at another six-year high on Friday as investors welcomed recent market-boosting comments by the central bank, brokers said.
The benchmark stock index ended 81.68 points or 1.01 percent higher at 8,162.68.
Friday's close surpassed the 8,081.00 finish on Thursday and marked the index's highest level since it reached 8,569.55 on May 15, 1990.
Turnover was a hectic T$149.717 billion.
Most sectors saw gains, with construction and paper shares rising 3.99 percent and 3.75 percent respectively.
Cathay Construction gained T$3.40 to T$52.50, while Pacific Construction rose T$1.60 to T$28.90.
Chung Hwa Pulp rose T$1.90 to T$29.90.

"The fervour lingers and it was due mostly to recent comments by the government that it would not take new actions to restrain the market despite sharp rallies," Oliver Fang, an analyst of National Securities, said.
Fang said construction shares were red-hot on Friday due mainly to a government decision to grant preferential low-interest loans for property developers.
Expected price hikes of pulp also boosted paper shares, he added.
Analysts said the central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong's pledge to refrain from intervening in the stock market despite recent sharp rallies was maintaining bullish sentiment.
Sheu Yuan-dong told parliament on Thursday he was "a bit worried" about the island's surging stock market, but the central would not intervene in the bourse.
The stock index has risen more than 1,200 points so far this year.
A range of 8,100 to 8,250 points was seen for Saturday.
